Simultaneous Wireless Information and Power Transfer for Federated Learning

José Mairton Barros da Silva Jr.⋆, Konstantinos Ntougias‡, Ioannis Krikidis‡, Gábor Fodor⋆†, Carlo Fischione⋆
⋆School of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, KTH Royal Institute of Technology, Stockholm, Sweden
‡Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Cyprus, Nicosia, Cyprus
†Ericsson Research, Kista, Sweden
Email: {⋆{}^{\star}\{jmbdsj, gaborf, carlofi}@\}@kth.se, {‡{}^{\ddagger}\{ntougias.konstantinos, krikidis.ioannis}@\}@ucy.ac.cy The simulations were performed on resources provided by the Swedish National Infrastructure for Computing (SNIC) at PDC Centre for High Performance Computing (PDC-HPC). This work has received funding from the European Research Council (ERC) under the European Union’s Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme (Grant agreement No. 819819).
(March 1, 2024)
Abstract

In the Internet of Things, learning is one of most prominent tasks. In this paper, we consider an Internet of Things scenario where federated learning is used with simultaneous transmission of model data and wireless power. We investigate the trade-off between the number of communication rounds and communication round time while harvesting energy to compensate the energy expenditure. We formulate and solve an optimization problem by considering the number of local iterations on devices, the time to transmit-receive the model updates, and to harvest sufficient energy. Numerical results indicate that maximum ratio transmission and zero-forcing beamforming for the optimization of the local iterations on devices substantially boost the test accuracy of the learning task. Moreover, maximum ratio transmission instead of zero-forcing provides the best test accuracy and communication round time trade-off for various energy harvesting percentages. Thus, it is possible to learn a model quickly with few communication rounds without depleting the battery.

Keywords:
Federated learning, IoT, SWIPT, communication round and time minimization, energy harvesting

I Introduction

Internet of Things (IoT) devices will arguably generate large amount of data, which can be of great use for prediction and inference in several applications of major societal interest [1]. Thus, it is natural to push machine learning solution into the Internet of Things (IoT) devices [2]. However, machine learning is traditionally conceived in centralized settings, where all data is available at one location. When we use machine learning on distributed wireless scenarios, such as the IoT applications, we encounter new challenges for both learning (such as heterogeneity of the data generated by the distributed devices and privacy issues [3]), and communication (such as communication efficiency, interference channel, fading, and battery limitations [4]).

Federated learning (FL) is a recently proposed distributed machine learning technique that attempts to overcome some of these challenges, since it enhances the privacy by sending only model updates instead of raw data, and considers the heterogeneity of devices data and the communication efficiency in the learning convergence [3]. For IoT scenarios, the limited energy storage capacity and high maintenance cost of devices battery is the main challenge [5]. To this end, federated learning (FL) in IoT scenarios must consider the battery of the devices as one of the most important aspects, together with the impact of communication efficiency, interference, and fading.

One promising solution to overcome the energy limitations in IoT is energy harvesting, which allows devices to harvest radio frequency energy when communicating with an edge server, e.g., a base station or access point [6]. Hence, the use of energy harvesting for IoT devices with FL would be a perfect combination. However, how to allow the devices to harvest sufficient energy to train a FL model is largely an open question. This idea is highly novel and, to the best of our knowledge, there is only one similar work in the literature [7]. In [7], the authors consider a wireless power transfer scenario served by power-beacons using FL. Such a work shows that higher density of power beacons improves the learning convergence, and that the mini-batch size and processor clock frequency is inversely proportional to the energy spent in local computation.

Different from the authors in [7], we investigate the trade-off among the number of communication rounds between an edge server and the IoT devices, and the communication round time necessary to train, transmit, and receive the model while harvesting sufficient energy to compensate part of the total energy spent. This trade-off is important to understand in which conditions we can train a FL task without depleting the battery of the devices. We consider a scenario with a multi-antenna edge server using the simultaneous wireless information and power transfer (SWIPT) technology with IoT devices using FL to simultaneously train a learning model, while communicating with an edge server (see Figure 1). Moreover, we consider the use of FedProx [8], a recent generalization of FL that allows to optimize the number of local iterations at each device, while guaranteeing convergence to (non-)convex learning tasks. We propose an optimization problem to minimize the number of communication rounds and communication round time while optimizing the number of local iterations, the time to transmit/receive, and to harvest a percentage of the total energy spent at each round and device.

We provide the solution to this problem while considering low transmit power at devices and fixed beamforming techniques, e.g., maximum ratio transmission (MRT) and zero-forcing (ZF), at the edge server. The results indicate that the learning test accuracy using either MRT or ZF with the optimization of the local number of iterations outperform a solution without such optimization. We also show that MRT vastly outperforms ZF in terms of minimum communication round time for all the percentage of the energy harvesting required. Therefore, we show that it is possible to use FL in IoT scenarios without depleting the battery of the devices.

II System Model

We consider a general IoT scenario with an edge server equipped with M𝑀M antennas and K𝐾K single-antenna devices (see Figure 1). The devices represent sensors gathering data for an FL task and a power splitting SWIPT receiver architecture [6, 9]. In the following, we define the communication, energy, time, and learning models.

II-B Energy and Time Models

We define the energy consumption to compute the model at device k𝑘k as [10]

Ekc=κ​Ck​Ak​Ik​fk2,superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘𝑐𝜅subscript𝐶𝑘subscript𝐴𝑘subscript𝐼𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑘2E_{k}^{c}=\kappa C_{k}A_{k}I_{k}f_{k}^{2}, (8)

where κ𝜅\kappa is the effective switched capacitance, Cksubscript𝐶𝑘C_{k} is the number of central processing unit cycles required for computing one sample data at device in Mcycles/bit, Aksubscript𝐴𝑘A_{k} is the dataset size in bits at device k𝑘k, Iksubscript𝐼𝑘I_{k} is the number of local iterations performed in the training phase by the learning algorithm, and fksubscript𝑓𝑘f_{k} is the processor clock frequency at device k𝑘k in GHz. Assuming that the uplink transmission occurs during tkusuperscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘𝑢t_{k}^{u} seconds and the transmitted power is pksubscript𝑝𝑘p_{k}, the energy to transmit the weights in the uplink is Ekt=tku​pksuperscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘𝑢subscript𝑝𝑘E_{k}^{t}=t_{k}^{u}p_{k}. Hence, the total energy spent at device k𝑘k during one communication round is Ekc+Ektsuperscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘𝑐superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘𝑡E_{k}^{c}+E_{k}^{t}.

We consider a nonlinear energy harvesting model as in [11], in which the harvested power Pkhsuperscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘ℎP_{k}^{h} is given by

Pkh=α1​((1−δk)​Pkr)2+α2​((1−δk)​Pkr)+α3,superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘ℎsubscript𝛼1superscript1subscript𝛿𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘𝑟2subscript𝛼21subscript𝛿𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘𝑟subscript𝛼3\displaystyle P_{k}^{h}=\alpha_{1}\left((1-\delta_{k})P_{k}^{r}\right)^{2}+\alpha_{2}\left((1-\delta_{k})P_{k}^{r}\right)+\alpha_{3}, (9)

where α1,α2,α3∈ℝsubscript𝛼1subscript𝛼2subscript𝛼3ℝ\alpha_{1},\alpha_{2},\alpha_{3}\in\mathbb{R} are parameters of the model. We define the energy harvested at device k𝑘k as Ekh=tkd​Pkhsubscriptsuperscript𝐸ℎ𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘ℎE^{h}_{k}=t_{k}^{d}P_{k}^{h}, where tkdsuperscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘𝑑t_{k}^{d} is the transmission time in seconds that the edge server spends to unicast the aggregated weight to device k𝑘k. Therefore, we constraint the total energy spent by the total harvested energy at device k𝑘k, i.e., Ekt+Ekc≤Ekhsuperscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘𝑐subscriptsuperscript𝐸ℎ𝑘E_{k}^{t}+E_{k}^{c}\leq E^{h}_{k}.

In the uplink, we assume that device k𝑘k has Dksubscript𝐷𝑘D_{k} bits to transmit, corresponding to the dimension of the weight updates multiplied by the number of bits used to represent each dimension. Thus, each device k𝑘k has a constraint tku​Rku≥Dksuperscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘𝑢superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑘𝑢subscript𝐷𝑘t_{k}^{u}R_{k}^{u}\geq D_{k} in the uplink. Similarly, the downlink rate must ensure that the aggregated weight is unicasted to each device. Hence, each device k𝑘k has a constraint tkd​Rkd≥Dksuperscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑘𝑑subscript𝐷𝑘t_{k}^{d}R_{k}^{d}\geq D_{k} in the downlink.

In addition, we need to take into account the time necessary for device k𝑘k to solve the local problem. Let us denote the time to solve the local training problem device k𝑘k as [10]

tkc=Ck​Ak​Ik/fk,superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘𝑐subscript𝐶𝑘subscript𝐴𝑘subscript𝐼𝑘subscript𝑓𝑘\displaystyle t_{k}^{c}=C_{k}A_{k}I_{k}/f_{k}, (10)

where Cksubscript𝐶𝑘C_{k}, Aksubscript𝐴𝑘A_{k}, Iksubscript𝐼𝑘I_{k}, and fksubscript𝑓𝑘f_{k} are the same parameters as in Eq. (8). Therefore, we denote the time for one communication round, including the uplink transmission with local computation, and downlink transmission with harvesting time, as tr=maxk⁡(tku+tkc)+maxk⁡(tkd)superscript𝑡𝑟subscript𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘𝑢superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘𝑐subscript𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘𝑑t^{r}=\max_{k}\;(t_{k}^{u}+t_{k}^{c})+\max_{k}\;(t_{k}^{d}).

II-C Learning Model

The FL methods [3, 8] are designed to support multiple devices collecting data and a server (edge server in our case) coordinating the global learning objective for the network. The objective of the network is to solve the problem below:

minimize𝐰𝐰minimize\displaystyle\underset{\mathbf{w}}{\text{minimize}} f​(𝐰)=∑k=1KNkN​Fk​(𝐰),𝑓𝐰superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑁𝑘𝑁subscript𝐹𝑘𝐰\displaystyle f(\mathbf{w})=\sum\nolimits_{k=1}^{K}\frac{N_{k}}{N}F_{k}(\mathbf{w}), (11)

where N=∑k=1KNk𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑁𝑘N=\sum_{k=1}^{K}N_{k} and 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w} is the global weight of the network. The devices measure the local empirical risk over different data distributions 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k}, i.e. Fk​(𝐰)≜𝔼𝐗k∼𝒟k​[fk​(𝐰;𝐗k)]≜subscript𝐹𝑘𝐰subscript𝔼similar-tosubscript𝐗𝑘subscript𝒟𝑘delimited-[]subscript𝑓𝑘𝐰subscript𝐗𝑘F_{k}(\mathbf{w})\triangleq\mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{X}_{k}\sim\mathcal{D}_{k}}[f_{k}(\mathbf{w};\mathbf{X}_{k})] in which the expectation is over the Nksubscript𝑁𝑘N_{k} samples held by device k𝑘k. The function fk​(𝐰;𝐗k)subscript𝑓𝑘𝐰subscript𝐗𝑘f_{k}(\mathbf{w};\mathbf{X}_{k}) is the loss function at device k𝑘k using its local dataset 𝐗ksubscript𝐗𝑘\mathbf{X}_{k} and the global weight 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w}. To reduce the communication of the weights for each device, FL methods consider that each device k𝑘k minimizes the loss function Fk​(𝐰k)≜𝔼𝐗k∼𝒟k​[fk​(𝐰k;𝐗k)]≜subscript𝐹𝑘subscript𝐰𝑘subscript𝔼similar-tosubscript𝐗𝑘subscript𝒟𝑘delimited-[]subscript𝑓𝑘subscript𝐰𝑘subscript𝐗𝑘F_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{k})\triangleq\mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{X}_{k}\sim\mathcal{D}_{k}}[f_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{k};\mathbf{X}_{k})] by using its own data 𝐗ksubscript𝐗𝑘\mathbf{X}_{k} and with its own weights 𝐰ksubscript𝐰𝑘\mathbf{w}_{k}. Then, the devices send the resulting 𝐰ksubscript𝐰𝑘\mathbf{w}_{k} to the edge server, which aggregates the weights from each device and sends back the global weight 𝐰=∑k=1K(Nk/N)​𝐰k𝐰superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑁𝑘𝑁subscript𝐰𝑘\mathbf{w}=\sum_{k=1}^{K}(N_{k}/N)\mathbf{w}_{k}. The devices use the global weight as the initial point to minimize Fk​(𝐰k)subscript𝐹𝑘subscript𝐰𝑘F_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{k}), and this process continues until problem (11) converges to the optimal solution.

The FL approach considered is FedProx [8], which guarantees convergence for scenarios with heterogeneous devices and non-convex learning objectives. Due to these advantages, FedProx suits particularly well IoT. To further reduce communication exchange among the edge server and the devices, the local objective function is a surrogate for the global objective function. The surrogate function hk​(𝐰k;𝐰t)subscriptℎ𝑘subscript𝐰𝑘superscript𝐰𝑡h_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{k};\mathbf{w}^{t}) includes a proximal term to the local subproblem with the global update 𝐰tsuperscript𝐰𝑡\mathbf{w}^{t} at communication round t𝑡t. Thus, each device k𝑘k solves the following local training problem

minimize𝐰ksubscript𝐰𝑘minimize\displaystyle\underset{\mathbf{w}_{k}}{\text{minimize}} hk​(𝐰k;𝐰t)=Fk​(𝐰k)+μ2​‖𝐰k−𝐰t‖2,subscriptℎ𝑘subscript𝐰𝑘superscript𝐰𝑡subscript𝐹𝑘subscript𝐰𝑘𝜇2superscriptnormsubscript𝐰𝑘superscript𝐰𝑡2\displaystyle\;h_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{k};\mathbf{w}^{t})=F_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{k})+\frac{\mu}{2}\left\|\mathbf{w}_{k}-\mathbf{w}^{t}\right\|^{2}, (12)

where μ>0𝜇0\mu>0 is a local configurable parameter. In addition to computing the surrogate function, each device may solve problem (12) inexactly so that a flexible performance depending on the local computation capacity and communication may be included in the solution. Specifically, we introduce the γktsuperscriptsubscript𝛾𝑘𝑡\gamma_{k}^{t}-inexactness for device k𝑘k at round t𝑡t below.

Definition 1 (γktsuperscriptsubscript𝛾𝑘𝑡\gamma_{k}^{t}-inexact solution).

For a function hk​(𝐰k;𝐰t)=Fk​(𝐰k)+(μ/2)​‖𝐰k−𝐰t‖2subscriptℎ𝑘subscript𝐰𝑘superscript𝐰𝑡subscript𝐹𝑘subscript𝐰𝑘𝜇2superscriptnormsubscript𝐰𝑘superscript𝐰𝑡2h_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{k};\mathbf{w}^{t})=F_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{k})+(\mu/2)\left\|\mathbf{w}_{k}-\mathbf{w}^{t}\right\|^{2}, and γkt∈[0,1]superscriptsubscript𝛾𝑘𝑡01\gamma_{k}^{t}\in[0,1], we define 𝐰k(n)superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑘𝑛\mathbf{w}_{k}^{(n)} as the γktsuperscriptsubscript𝛾𝑘𝑡\gamma_{k}^{t}-inexact solution of problem minimize𝐰k​hk​(𝐰k;𝐰t)subscript𝐰𝑘minimizesubscriptℎ𝑘subscript𝐰𝑘superscript𝐰𝑡\underset{\mathbf{w}_{k}}{\text{minimize}}\;h_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{k};\mathbf{w}^{t}) at iteration n𝑛n if

‖∇hk​(𝐰k(n);𝐰t)‖≤γkt​‖∇hk​(𝐰t;𝐰t)‖,norm∇subscriptℎ𝑘superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑘𝑛superscript𝐰𝑡superscriptsubscript𝛾𝑘𝑡norm∇subscriptℎ𝑘superscript𝐰𝑡superscript𝐰𝑡\left\|\nabla h_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{k}^{(n)};\mathbf{w}^{t})\right\|\leq\gamma_{k}^{t}\left\|\nabla h_{k}(\mathbf{w}^{t};\mathbf{w}^{t})\right\|,

where ∇hk​(𝐰k;𝐰t)=∇Fk​(𝐰k)+μ​(𝐰k−𝐰t).∇subscriptℎ𝑘subscript𝐰𝑘superscript𝐰𝑡∇subscript𝐹𝑘subscript𝐰𝑘𝜇subscript𝐰𝑘superscript𝐰𝑡\nabla h_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{k};\mathbf{w}^{t})=\nabla F_{k}(\mathbf{w}_{k})+\mu(\mathbf{w}_{k}-\mathbf{w}^{t}).

Hence, problem (12) is solved using stochastic gradient descent (SGD) and iterates until a γktsuperscriptsubscript𝛾𝑘𝑡\gamma_{k}^{t}-inexact solution is obtained. The iterations are local at device k𝑘k and are termed epochs. Different than the traditional federated averaging method [3], the number of epochs in FedProx is controlled by γktsuperscriptsubscript𝛾𝑘𝑡\gamma_{k}^{t} and may be different for each device.

From [8, Theorem 4 and Corollary 9], the convergence of FedProx is as follows.

Theorem 1 (Convergence: Variable γ𝛾\gamma’s).

Assume the functions Fksubscript𝐹𝑘F_{k} are non-convex, L𝐿L-Lipschitz smooth, and there exists L−>0subscript𝐿0L_{-}>0, such that ∇2Fk⪰−L−​𝐈succeeds-or-equalssuperscript∇2subscript𝐹𝑘subscript𝐿𝐈\nabla^{2}F_{k}\succeq-L_{-}\mathbf{I}, with μ¯≜μ−L−>0≜¯𝜇𝜇subscript𝐿0\bar{\mu}\triangleq\mu-L_{-}>0. Consider that B𝐵B is a global measure of dissimilarity between the gradients of the devices [8, Definition 3], and suppose that 𝐰tsuperscript𝐰𝑡\mathbf{w}^{t} is not a stationary solution and the local functions Fksubscript𝐹𝑘F_{k} are B𝐵B-dissimilar. If μ𝜇\mu, K𝐾K, and γktsuperscriptsubscript𝛾𝑘𝑡\gamma_{k}^{t} are chosen such that

ρ𝜌\displaystyle\rho =((1−γt​B)μ−(1+γt)​(a1+a2​(1+γt)))>0,absent1superscript𝛾𝑡𝐵𝜇1superscript𝛾𝑡subscript𝑎1subscript𝑎21superscript𝛾𝑡0\displaystyle=\left(\frac{(1-\gamma^{t}B)}{\mu}-(1+\gamma^{t})(a_{1}+a_{2}(1+\gamma^{t}))\right)>0, (13)

then at communication round t𝑡t of FedProx, we have the following expected decrease ρ𝜌\rho in the global objective

𝔼St​[f​(𝐰t+1)]≤f​(𝐰t)−ρ​‖∇f​(𝐰t)‖2,subscript𝔼subscript𝑆𝑡delimited-[]𝑓superscript𝐰𝑡1𝑓superscript𝐰𝑡𝜌superscriptnorm∇𝑓superscript𝐰𝑡2\mathbb{E}_{S_{t}}[f(\mathbf{w}^{t+1})]\leq f(\mathbf{w}^{t})-\rho\left\|\nabla f(\mathbf{w}^{t})\right\|^{2},

where Stsubscript𝑆𝑡S_{t} is the set of K𝐾K devices selected at iteration t𝑡t, γt=maxk∈St⁡γktsuperscript𝛾𝑡subscript𝑘subscript𝑆𝑡superscriptsubscript𝛾𝑘𝑡\gamma^{t}=\max_{k\in S_{t}}\leavevmode\nobreak\ {\gamma_{k}^{t}}, and the constants a1,a2subscript𝑎1subscript𝑎2a_{1},\;a_{2} are

a1=B​μ​2+L​B​Kμ​μ¯​K,a2=L​B22​μ¯2​K​(K+4​2​K+4).∎formulae-sequencesubscript𝑎1𝐵𝜇2𝐿𝐵𝐾𝜇¯𝜇𝐾subscript𝑎2𝐿superscript𝐵22superscript¯𝜇2𝐾𝐾42𝐾4\displaystyle a_{1}=\frac{B\mu\sqrt{2}+LB\sqrt{K}}{\mu\bar{\mu}\sqrt{K}},\quad a_{2}=\frac{LB^{2}}{2\bar{\mu}^{2}K}(K+4\sqrt{2}K+4).\qed

In the following, we drop the index t𝑡t in γkt,γtsuperscriptsubscript𝛾𝑘𝑡superscript𝛾𝑡\gamma_{k}^{t},\;\gamma^{t} and refer to them as γk,γsubscript𝛾𝑘𝛾\gamma_{k},\;\gamma to simplify notation, and consider that Stsubscript𝑆𝑡S_{t} corresponds to all devices K𝐾K. Moreover, the conditions in [8, Remark 5] that ensure ρ>0𝜌0\rho>0, i.e., that sufficient decrease is attainable after each communication round, are the following

γ​B<1,B<K.formulae-sequence𝛾𝐵1𝐵𝐾\displaystyle\gamma B<1,\quad B<\sqrt{K}. (14)

Then, the authors in [8, Theorem 6] characterize the rate of convergence to the set of approximate stationary solutions 𝒮s={𝐰|𝔼​[‖∇f​(𝐰)‖2]≤ϵ}subscript𝒮𝑠conditional-set𝐰𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm∇𝑓𝐰2italic-ϵ\mathcal{S}_{s}=\{\mathbf{w}\;|\;\mathbb{E}[\left\|\nabla f(\mathbf{w})\right\|^{2}]\leq\epsilon\} of problem (11). Finally, the total number of communication rounds of FedProx is T=O​(Δρ​ϵ)𝑇𝑂Δ𝜌italic-ϵT=O(\frac{\Delta}{\rho\epsilon}), where Δ=f​(𝐰1)−f∗Δ𝑓superscript𝐰1superscript𝑓\Delta=f(\mathbf{w}^{1})-f^{*}.

In order to define the optimization problem, we first need to derive the number of local iterations (epochs) Iksubscript𝐼𝑘I_{k}, which depends on the solver used to obtain the optimal 𝐰k⋆superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑘⋆\mathbf{w}_{k}^{\star} that provides the γksubscript𝛾𝑘\gamma_{k}-inexact solution. In the following theorem, we establish the expression for Iksubscript𝐼𝑘I_{k} in terms of γksubscript𝛾𝑘\gamma_{k}.

Theorem 2.

Consider that the initial iteration for device k𝑘k is given by 𝐰k0=𝐰tsuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑘0superscript𝐰𝑡\mathbf{w}_{k}^{0}=\mathbf{w}^{t}, and that β=2/(α​μ¯​(2−α​(L+μ)))𝛽2𝛼¯𝜇2𝛼𝐿𝜇\beta=2/(\alpha\bar{\mu}\left(2-\alpha(L+\mu)\right)). Ik≥2​β​log⁡(L+μγkt​μ¯).subscript𝐼𝑘2𝛽𝐿𝜇superscriptsubscript𝛾𝑘𝑡¯𝜇\displaystyle I_{k}\geq 2\beta\log\left(\frac{L+\mu}{\gamma_{k}^{t}\bar{\mu}}\right). (15)
Proof.

See Appendix A. ∎

Based on the theoretical guarantees for the convergence of FedProx, we can now properly formulate the problem in the next section.

III Minimization of Communication Rounds and Round Time

Our objective is to minimize the number of communication rounds between the edge server and the devices, while minimizing the time for each communication round and ensuring that sufficient energy is harvested by the devices. We consider the total number of communication rounds between the edge server and the devices from Section II-C. Given that the term ΔΔ\Delta cannot be estimated beforehand, we disregard ΔΔ\Delta and assume that the total number of communication rounds is Ig​(ρ,ϵ)=1/(ρ​ϵ)subscript𝐼𝑔𝜌italic-ϵ1𝜌italic-ϵI_{g}(\rho,\epsilon)\!\!=\!\!1/(\rho\epsilon). Since we aim to minimize the number of communication rounds Ig​(ρ,ϵ)subscript𝐼𝑔𝜌italic-ϵI_{g}(\rho,\epsilon), we can maximize ρ𝜌\rho, i.e., the expected decrease in the global objective function per communication round, due to its monotonic decreasing relation with Ig​(ρ,ϵ)subscript𝐼𝑔𝜌italic-ϵI_{g}(\rho,\epsilon).

We formulate the trade-off between the number of communication rounds and the communication round time using SWIPT to harvest while learning as

minimize{tku},{tkd},{γk},γsuperscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘𝑢superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘𝑑subscript𝛾𝑘𝛾minimize\displaystyle\underset{\begin{subarray}{c}\{t_{k}^{u}\},\{t_{k}^{d}\},\{\gamma_{k}\},\gamma\end{subarray}}{\text{minimize}}\quad tr−ρsuperscript𝑡𝑟𝜌\displaystyle t^{r}-\rho (16a)
subject to tku​Rku≥Dk,∀k,superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘𝑢superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑘𝑢subscript𝐷𝑘for-all𝑘\displaystyle t_{k}^{u}R_{k}^{u}\geq D_{k},\forall k, (16b)
tkd​Rkd≥Dk,∀k,superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑘𝑑subscript𝐷𝑘for-all𝑘\displaystyle t_{k}^{d}R_{k}^{d}\geq D_{k},\forall k, (16c)
Ekh≥ζ​(Ekt+Ekc),∀k,subscriptsuperscript𝐸ℎ𝑘𝜁superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘𝑐for-all𝑘\displaystyle E^{h}_{k}\geq\zeta\left(E_{k}^{t}+E_{k}^{c}\right),\forall k, (16d)
γk≤1−ξB,∀k,subscript𝛾𝑘1𝜉𝐵for-all𝑘\displaystyle\gamma_{k}\leq\frac{1-\xi}{B},\forall k, (16e)
γ≥γk,∀k,𝛾subscript𝛾𝑘for-all𝑘\displaystyle\gamma\geq\gamma_{k},\forall k, (16f)
tku,tkd,γk≥0,∀k,formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘𝑢superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘𝑑subscript𝛾𝑘0for-all𝑘\displaystyle t_{k}^{u},t_{k}^{d},\gamma_{k}\geq 0,\forall k, (16g)

where the objective is to minimize the number of communication rounds and the communication round time. The constraints (16b)-(16c) state that all the data should be transmitted to the edge server and then received by device k𝑘k; constraint (16d) states that at least a ζ∈(0,1]𝜁01\zeta\in(0,1] part of the total energy used by device k𝑘k should be harvested; constraint (16e) states the maximum value for γksubscript𝛾𝑘\gamma_{k} is constrained according to Eq. (14), in which ξ∈[0,1]𝜉01\xi\in[0,1] is a predefined constant to turn the strict inequality into a non-strict inequality; and constraint (16g) states that all variables should be nonzero.

III-A Solution Approach

For ease of notation, we rewrite the terms that include γksubscript𝛾𝑘\gamma_{k} in the objective function and constraints of problem (16). First, we can rewrite the energy to compute the model at device k𝑘k, Ekcsuperscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘𝑐E_{k}^{c}, in Eq. (8) as

Ekc=a3,k​(log⁡(a4)−log⁡(γk)),superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑘𝑐subscript𝑎3𝑘subscript𝑎4subscript𝛾𝑘\displaystyle E_{k}^{c}=a_{3,k}\left(\log(a_{4})-\log(\gamma_{k})\right), (17)

where the parameters a3,k,a4subscript𝑎3𝑘subscript𝑎4a_{3,k},\;a_{4} denote the following

a3,k=2​κ​β​Ck​Ak​fk2,∀k,a4=(L+μ)/μ¯.formulae-sequencesubscript𝑎3𝑘2𝜅𝛽subscript𝐶𝑘subscript𝐴𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑘2for-all𝑘subscript𝑎4𝐿𝜇¯𝜇\displaystyle a_{3,k}=2\kappa\beta C_{k}A_{k}f_{k}^{2},\;\forall k,\quad a_{4}=(L+\mu)/\bar{\mu}.

Similarly, we denote the time to compute the model, tkcsuperscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘𝑐t_{k}^{c}, as

tkc=a5,k​(log⁡(a4)−log⁡(γk)),a5,k=2​β​Ck​Ak/fk.formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘𝑐subscript𝑎5𝑘subscript𝑎4subscript𝛾𝑘subscript𝑎5𝑘2𝛽subscript𝐶𝑘subscript𝐴𝑘subscript𝑓𝑘\displaystyle t_{k}^{c}=a_{5,k}\left(\log(a_{4})-\log(\gamma_{k})\right),\quad a_{5,k}=2\beta C_{k}A_{k}/f_{k}.

With these reformulations, we can rewrite problem (16) in an equivalent form as

minimizeγ,{γk},{tku},{tkd}𝛾subscript𝛾𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘𝑢superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘𝑑minimize\displaystyle\underset{\begin{subarray}{c}\gamma,\{\gamma_{k}\},\\ \{t_{k}^{u}\},\{t_{k}^{d}\}\end{subarray}}{\text{minimize}}\quad (maxk⁡(a5,k​(log⁡(a4/γk))+tku)+maxk⁡(tkd))+limit-fromsubscript𝑘subscript𝑎5𝑘subscript𝑎4subscript𝛾𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘𝑢subscript𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘𝑑\displaystyle\left(\max_{k}\left(a_{5,k}\left(\log(a_{4}/\gamma_{k})\right)+t_{k}^{u}\right)+\max_{k}(t_{k}^{d})\right)+

Note that problem (18) is jointly convex on all variables because the objective function is concave, while the constraints are convex. Hence, it can be solved by using traditional convex solvers, such as interior-point methods present on CVXPY [12]. The computational complexity is 𝒪​(K4)𝒪superscript𝐾4\mathcal{O}(K^{4}) [13], which is due to the use of interior-point methods to solve problem (18).

IV Numerical Results

We consider a system comprised by a single pico-cell [14]. The total number of antennas at the edge server is M=16𝑀16M=16 and the total number of devices is K=10𝐾10K=10. We consider an image classification learning task using the MNIST dataset and a multi-class logistic regression as loss function. The samples per device Nksubscript𝑁𝑘N_{k} are randomly assigned to the devices in a non-IID manner, which ensures that a device will have tens or thousands of samples, and consider 323232 bits encoding, i.e., Ak=32​Nksubscript𝐴𝑘32subscript𝑁𝑘A_{k}=32N_{k}. We consider maximum ratio combining (MRC) at the receiver and two transmitter beamforming options namely, MRT and ZF. The test accuracy is the performance indicator used for learning tasks because it represents the percentage of correct predictions. The parameters necessary to obtain the numerical results are listed in Table I.

Figure 2 shows the average test accuracy versus the number of communication rounds over 10 Monte Carlo iterations using a baseline FedProx with only one epoch, i.e., without γksubscript𝛾𝑘\gamma_{k} optimization and using only one SGD iteration. We compare it with the solution of problem (18) by using MRT and ZF beamforming. We assume that ζ=1.0𝜁1.0\zeta=1.0, which means that in each round the devices must harvest all the total energy spent with the training and transmission. Note that the shaded region for the curves represent the standard deviation at each communication round. Without γksubscript𝛾𝑘\gamma_{k} optimization, the average test accuracy increases much slower than the MRT and ZF solutions using γksubscript𝛾𝑘\gamma_{k} optimization. For instance, at 20 communication rounds the average test accuracy of MRT and ZF are approximately 82%percent8282\,\mathrm{\%}, while with one epoch it is only 69%percent6969\,\mathrm{\%}. Moreover, there is almost no difference in the average and standard deviation of the test accuracy for MRT and ZF, which is due to a similar number of local iterations from the solution of problem (18). The energy received by ZF is lower than MRT because ZF nulls the interference from neighbouring users, and thus causes inequality (18c) harder to be attainable. To fulfil inequality (18c), the downlink time is increased and the value of γksubscript𝛾𝑘\gamma_{k} is decreased, but kept at similar values for both ZF and MRT. Therefore, there are substantial benefits in terms of communication rounds, when optimizing the learning parameters (γk)subscript𝛾𝑘(\gamma_{k}) based on the solution of problem (18).

Figure 3 shows the average communication round time, trsuperscript𝑡𝑟t^{r}, across all Monte Carlo iterations versus the percentage of energy harvesting required ζ𝜁\zeta, when using MRT and ZF beamforming. As ζ𝜁\zeta increases from 10%percent1010\,\mathrm{\%} to 100%percent100100\,\mathrm{\%}, the communication round time increases much faster for ZF than MRT. It indicates that this difference is due to tkdsuperscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘𝑑t_{k}^{d} and that inequality (18c), instead of inequality (16c), is the bottleneck for both MRT and ZF. Since ZF nulls the interference from neighbouring users, the total received and harvested power is lower than the MRT case, as expected from the energy harvesting literature [9]. Moreover, it implies that the necessary time to harvest a ζ𝜁\zeta-percentage of the total energy used by device k𝑘k is much higher with ZF than MRT. Since MRT and ZF have practically the same test accuracy, the MRT beamforming is a better solution to use in a practical scenario because it provides the best trade-off in terms of test accuracy and energy harvesting capabilities within a short communication round time.

V Conclusion

In this paper, we considered the trade-off between the number of communication rounds in a FL model and the necessary communication round time to harvest energy in an IoT scenario. Specifically, our objective was to minimize the total number of communication rounds necessary to learn a model using FL while minimizing the communication round time, which includes the time to compute and transmit the model, and the time to harvest a sufficient amount of the energy spent during training and transmission. Considering fixed transmit beamforming, this resulted in an optimization problem with learning and time parameters that is jointly convex in all the parameters. The numerical results showed that the solution to this problem using either MRT or ZF beamforming achieves a much higher test accuracy than a baseline solution that does not optimize the learning parameters based on communication aspects. We showed that the MRT beamforming solution provides much lower communication round time than ZF beamforming, while achieving practically the same test accuracy. Therefore, we showed that MRT beamforming is able to achieve a much better trade-off in terms of number of communication rounds and communication round time. For future work, we intend to study the impact of using optimized beamforming and energy harvesting parameters together with the learning and time parameters in the aforementioned trade-off.

In the following proof, we refer to h​(𝐰k;𝐰t)ℎsubscript𝐰𝑘superscript𝐰𝑡h(\mathbf{w}_{k};\mathbf{w}^{t}) as h​(𝐰k)ℎsubscript𝐰𝑘h(\mathbf{w}_{k}), and refer to ∥⋅∥2\left\|\cdot\right\|_{2} as ∥⋅∥\left\|\cdot\right\| to ease the notation.
